pageIntro: Here you will find important words from the blockchain world and the Stellar network. Everything is explained in simple terms.
searchPlaceholder: Search term (z. B. Konto, Account, Muxed)
searchHint: The search finds words and explanations.

blockchain.title: Blockchain
blockchain.short: Gemeinsames digitales Kassenbuch – viele Computer speichern die gleichen Einträge.
blockchain.desc: A blockchain is like a digital ledger. Many computers store the same entries, so no one can secretly alter anything.

wallet.title: Wallet
wallet.short: Digital wallet that manages your keys.
wallet.desc: A wallet is your digital purse. It manages the keys you need to access your account and send transactions. A wallet can be a program, an app, or even just a piece of paper with your private key.

account.title: Account
account.short: A blockchain account can hold assets and send transactions.
account.desc: An account is the place on the blockchain where your assets are held. An account has a public address that begins with G. Multiple wallets can access the same account if they have the correct key.

addressG.title: G-address
addressG.short: The public key (beginnt mit G) of a Stellar account.
addressG.desc: The G address is the main address of a Stellar account. It begins with the letter G. You provide it to others so they can send you something.

publicKey.title: Public key
publicKey.short: Adresse, die du teilen darfst; bei Stellar meist die G‑Adresse.
publicKey.desc: The public key is the address that you are allowed to share. In Stellar, this is the G-address. Others use it to send you money.

privateKey.title: Secret key
privateKey.short: Password to the account – never share.
privateKey.desc: The secret key is your password for the account. Anyone who has this key can move your money. Never share it.

addressFederation.title: Federation address
addressFederation.short: Kurze Adresse wie E‑Mail, zeigt auf eine G‑Adresse.
addressFederation.desc: A federation address looks like an email. Example: name*domain.com. This short address points to a normal G-address. It is easier to remember.

addressMuxed.title: Muxed account
addressMuxed.short: M‑address with additional ID – shares a base account.
addressMuxed.desc: An M-address points to an existing Stellar account but has an additional unique identifier (ID). This allows, for example, the differentiation of multiple people or departments under the same G-address. Technically, the funds still belong to the main account.

multisig.title: Multisignature
multisig.short: Important actions require more than just a signature.
multisig.desc: Multi-Sig stands for multiple signatures. An important action requires more than one key. For example, you and a second key must both agree before something can be sent. This makes theft more difficult.

help.title: General explanation of a multi-signature (Multi-Signature) corporate account
help.intro: A company can use a joint blockchain account involving several authorized individuals. Typically, at least three signatories (Signer) are involved, such as management, financial officer, and compliance/backup. The goal is for individual persons to independently execute payments without any single person having sole control over or taking over the account.
help.problem: If a signer (Signer) has enough weight to execute payments and simultaneously enough weight for account changes, that person could remove other signers (Signer) or adjust the threshold/weighting (Thresholds) and thereby take over the account. Conversely, the original owner should also not be able to exclude other signers (Signer) without checks and balances. A multi-sig structure ensures that important decisions are always supported by multiple people collectively.
help.setupTitle: Example of a secure multi-sig structure with three signers
help.setupWeights:
In an example with three equivalent roles, all receive the same signature strength:
- Signer (Signer) A (management): weight 2
- Signer (Signer) B (Finanzen): weight 2
- Signer (Signer) C (Compliance/Backup): weight 2
help.setupThresholds:
Appropriate thresholds/weightings are set:
- Low (low_threshold): 1
- Medium (med_threshold): 2 (for payments and other medium actions)
- High (high_threshold): 4 (for structural changes like adding/removing signers (Signer) or changing the threshold/weighting (Thresholds))
This setup allows each authorized person to execute payments, but no single person can change the account structure alone.
help.behavior: With this configuration, payments can be carried out by any of the three authorized persons individually, because each individual's weight meets the medium threshold/weighting (Threshold). However, for structural changes such as removing a signatory (Signers), adjusting the thresholds/weightings, or merging or closing the account, the high threshold/weighting (high_threshold) is required. This value can only be reached if at least two of the three signatories (Signer) sign together. This way, the account remains flexible for everyday use while being well-protected against misuse.
help.removal: Wenn eine Person das Unternehmen verlässt oder nicht mehr vertrauenswürdig ist, können zwei der verbleibenden Unterzeichner (Signer) gemeinsam die Signaturrechte dieser Person entfernen. Kein einzelner Unterzeichner (Signer) – weder ein Mitarbeiter noch die Geschäftsführung – kann andere eigenständig aus dem Konto ausschließen. Der Entzug von Berechtigungen erfolgt also immer kontrolliert und nachvollziehbar durch mindestens zwei Verantwortliche.
help.summary: This type of multi-signature structure allows individual persons to process payments efficiently while keeping control of the account in the hands of multiple parties. It reduces the risk of account takeovers, protects against unilateral decisions, and is particularly suitable for corporate accounts where both security and operational flexibility are important.

multisigCorporate.title: Multisig in companies
multisigCorporate.short: Example multi-sig structure for company accounts with roles, weights, and thresholds.

trustline.title: Trustline
trustline.short: Agreement to hold a token from a specific issuer.
trustline.desc:
A trustline is like saying yes, I accept this token. By doing so, you indicate that your account is ready to hold a specific token from a specific issuer. Without a trustline, you cannot receive this token.

Example: A trustline is specified as CODE:ISSUER. For EURT from the issuer GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y…, it is EURT:GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y…

token.title: Token
token.short: Digital unit – e.g., money, points, or credits.
token.desc: A token is a digital unit on the blockchain. A token can represent money, points, or credit for a service.

asset.title: Asset
asset.short: Tokens on Stellar are always linked to the issuer.
asset.desc: On Stellar, a token is called an asset. An asset is always linked to an issuing account. For example, an account can issue a Euro token. This Euro token is then an asset.

xlm.title: XLM
xlm.short: Native currency of Stellar for fees and activation.
xlm.desc: XLM is the native currency of Stellar. You need XLM to pay fees and to start a new account.

mainnet.title: Mainnet
mainnet.desc: The real Stellar network with actual value. Transactions are final, and fees are paid in real XLM.

testnet.title: Testnet
testnet.short: Public practice network with no real value.
testnet.desc: A public practice network. Tokens have no real value. Ideal for learning and experimenting without risk.

memo.title: Memo
memo.desc: A memo is a small note that you can send along with a transaction. Often, an exchange requires a specific memo to know to whom the money belongs.

transaction.title: Transaction
transaction.short: Action on the blockchain, e.g., payment or trustline.
transaction.desc: A transaction is an action on the blockchain, such as sending money or establishing a trustline. A transaction is stored permanently once it is confirmed.

fee.title: Fee
fee.desc: The fee is a very small amount that you pay with every transaction. The fee goes to the network. On Stellar, the fees are very small.

ledger.title: Ledger
ledger.short: Chain of confirmed data and account balances.
ledger.desc: The ledger is the chain of all confirmed data. It shows which accounts own how much and which transactions have occurred. Anyone can check the ledger.

horizon.title: Horizon
horizon.short: API‑Dienst, über den Apps mit Stellar sprechen.
horizon.desc: Horizon is the service through which programs communicate with the Stellar blockchain. Our tool queries Horizon to load account balances and transactions.

horizonHistory.title: Horizon History
horizonHistory.short: Describes how far back the transaction history provided by public Horizon servers extends.
horizonHistory.desc: Die von der Stellar Development Foundation betriebenen öffentlichen Horizon-Server (Mainnet und Testnet) stellen nur eine begrenzte Historie zur Verfügung – derzeit ungefähr ein Jahr rückwirkend. Ältere Daten sind über diese kostenlosen Endpunkte nicht mehr abrufbar. Wenn du weiter in die Vergangenheit zurück musst, hast du im Wesentlichen zwei Optionen: (1) du betreibst einen eigenen Horizon-Node mit vollständiger History (inklusive History Archives), oder (2) du nutzt Drittanbieter- bzw. Bezahldienste, die historische Stellar-Daten langfristig speichern und zur Verfügung stellen.
horizonHistory.seeAlso: I'm sorry, there is no text provided for translation. Could you please provide the text you would like me to translate?

anchor.title: Anchor
anchor.short: Firma, die Fiat‑Geld mit Stellar verbindet.
anchor.desc: An anchor is a company that connects real money, such as euros or dollars, with Stellar. For example, you give the anchor euros and receive a euro token on Stellar in return.

exchange.title: Stock exchange
exchange.short: Place to buy and sell tokens.
exchange.desc: An exchange is a place where you can buy or sell tokens. Many exchanges require a KYC process, meaning identity verification, before you can withdraw money in euros or francs.

dex.title: DEX
dex.short: Decentralized exchange directly on the blockchain.
dex.desc: DEX stands for Decentralized Exchange. Here, people trade directly with each other on the blockchain. There is no single operator. Stellar has a DEX built-in directly.

liquidityPool.title: Liquidity pool
liquidityPool.short: Joint pool with two tokens for immediate exchange.
liquidityPool.desc: A liquidity pool is a shared pool containing two tokens. People deposit both tokens into it. Others can then immediately exchange these tokens. The depositors earn small fees for this service.

balanceClaimable.title: Claimable Balance
balanceClaimable.short: Reserved money that you still need to accept.
balanceClaimable.desc: A claimable balance is money that has already been reserved for you, but you still need to claim it. Only when you accept it does it go into your account.

protocolUpdate.title: Protocol Update
protocolUpdate.desc: A protocol update is an upgrade of the rules in the Stellar network, such as new features or security changes. All nodes in the network must use the same rules.

soroban.title: Soroban
soroban.desc: Soroban is the smart contract system of Stellar. A smart contract is program code on the blockchain. The code can independently verify rules and trigger actions without an intermediary bank.

multiSignature.title: Multisignature
multiSignature.short: Multiple signatures required; weights + threshold determine the release.
multiSignature.desc: In a multi-signature setup, multiple keys must sign before an action becomes valid. Each signer has a weight, and the sum must reach the required threshold. This increases security because a single stolen key is not sufficient.

signer.title: Signatory
signer.short: Public key with weight, part of the account configuration.
signer.desc:
A signer is a public key that belongs to an account and has a weight. Its signature counts towards the required threshold. Multiple signers can collectively authorize a transaction.

Signer types:
- ed25519 (regular key)
- hashX (hash preimage)
- preAuthTx (pre-authorized transaction)

SKM supports only ed25519. For other options, see https://lab.stellar.org.

thresholds.title: Thresholds
thresholds.short: Limits (low/med/high) that determine the required sum of weights.
thresholds.desc: Thresholds define how many weighted signatures are necessary for actions: low for simple operations, med for payments, high for critical changes. The sum of the signers' weights must meet the respective threshold.

masterWeight.title: Master weight
masterWeight.short: Weight of the master key; controls how much the main key counts.
masterWeight.desc: The master weight is the weight of the main key of an account. A high master weight allows the master key to sign many actions alone; a low value requires additional signers.

accountConfig.title: Account configuration
accountConfig.short: The interplay of signers and thresholds determines the security of the account.
accountConfig.desc: The account configuration specifies which signers exist with which weights and what thresholds apply. Changes to signers or thresholds are security-critical because they determine how many signatures are required.

distributedNetwork.title: Distributed network
distributedNetwork.short: Many computers work together instead of one deciding everything.
distributedNetwork.desc: Imagine a market where many traders know the same rules. If one participant drops out, it continues to function because others can take over. This keeps the system stable and harder to manipulate.

node.title: Node
node.short: A single participant in the network.
node.desc: A node is like a ledger keeper that holds a copy of the data. It verifies new entries and forwards them. Many nodes together make the network reliable.

block.title: Block
block.short: A block is a package of entries.
block.desc: Like a page in a ledger, a block collects multiple transactions. Once it is full, it is finalized and added to the chain. This is how the history is created step by step.

consensusMechanism.title: Consensus mechanism
consensusMechanism.short: Rules by which everyone agrees on valid entries.
consensusMechanism.desc: It's like when a group decides which receipt is valid. This prevents anyone from secretly making changes. Different blockchains use different methods, but the goal is always consensus.

finality.title: Finality / Definitiveness
finality.short: The assurance that a transaction is final.
finality.desc: When something is final, it feels like a firmly booked bank statement. You no longer have to expect it to be reversed. This creates trust.

immutability.title: Immutability
immutability.short: Entries should not be altered retroactively.
immutability.desc: Just like with a cash book: Erasing afterward is noticeable. Changes are added as a new entry, not overwritten. This makes the history traceable.

decentralization.title: Decentralization
decentralization.desc: Instead of a single safe, there are many safes with the same information. Decisions arise from the interaction of many participants. This makes the system more robust.

publicBlockchain.title: Public blockchain
publicBlockchain.short: Open to anyone who wishes to participate.
publicBlockchain.desc: Anyone can participate and view the data, similar to a public notice board. This increases transparency, but every action is visible to everyone. Rules ensure that no one can cheat.

privateBlockchain.title: Private blockchain
privateBlockchain.desc: Like a company ledger that only employees are allowed to see. This can be quicker and more controlled, but it is less open. Trust is built here through the organization.

permissionlessBlockchain.title: Permissionless blockchain
permissionlessBlockchain.short: Everyone is allowed to participate without permission.
permissionlessBlockchain.desc: Like a market that anyone can join. This lowers barriers but might require more rules to remain fair. Examples include many public blockchains.

permissionedBlockchain.title: Permissioned Blockchain
permissionedBlockchain.desc: Like a club with a membership list. This can create clear responsibilities. However, it is less open.

seedPhrase.title: Restoration theorem
seedPhrase.short: A word list you can use to restore your wallet.
seedPhrase.desc: She is like the backup key to your safe. Whoever has it can restore your wallet. That's why it should never be stored online.

selfCustody.title: Self-custody
selfCustody.desc: Like having cash in your own safe: you have control, but also the responsibility. If you lose access, no one can help you. For beginners, caution is especially important.

custodian.title: Custodian
custodian.short: A service provider holds your keys for you.
custodian.desc: Like a bank that manages your account. It can be convenient, but it takes away your full control. You have to trust it.

hardwareWallet.title: Hardware wallet
hardwareWallet.short: A physical device for your keys.
hardwareWallet.desc: Like a small safe in your pocket. The keys remain on the device and do not go onto the internet. This protects against many online attacks.

hotWallet.title: Hot wallet
hotWallet.desc: Like a wallet in the jacket: convenient but more vulnerable. Suitable for small amounts and everyday use. Not ideal for large sums.

coldWallet.title: Cold wallet
coldWallet.short: A wallet without an internet connection.
coldWallet.desc: Like a safe in the basement. Very secure but impractical for everyday use. Suitable for long-term storage.

cryptocurrency.title: Cryptocurrency
cryptocurrency.short: Digital currency that is sent directly between people.
cryptocurrency.desc: Like digital cash, but without a bank. You can send it directly to others. The value can fluctuate.

altcoin.title: Altcoin
altcoin.desc: Like other brands in the market besides the industry leader. Some are well-known, many are small. Quality and risk vary greatly.

stablecoin.title: Stablecoin
stablecoin.short: Cryptocurrency with the most stable value.
stablecoin.desc: Like digital money that is pegged to a conventional currency. This makes its price more stable. Nevertheless, trust in the provider is important.

utilityToken.title: Usage token
utilityToken.short: A token with which one can use a service.
utilityToken.desc: Like a voucher at a market stall. It provides access or a discount. Its value depends on the usefulness of the service.

securityToken.title: Security tokens
securityToken.desc: Like a share certificate. It can promise rights or profits. Stricter rules often apply to it.

governanceToken.title: Governance token
governanceToken.short: A token for participating in decision-making about rules.
governanceToken.desc: Like a voting card in a club. Those who have tokens can vote on rules. That means responsibility.

liquidityToken.title: Liquidity tokens / LP tokens
liquidityToken.desc: It's like a receipt that you've contributed money to a joint fund. You receive proportional fees. The value can fluctuate.

nft.title: Non-fungible token / NFT
nft.desc: Like a signed collectible. It represents something unique, not an interchangeable coin. The value depends on demand.

cbdc.title: Central Bank Digital Currency / CBDC
cbdc.short: Digital currency issued by a central bank.
cbdc.desc: Like digital cash from the state. It would be official money, just in digital form. Details depend on the specific country.

transactionStatus.title: Transaction status
transactionStatus.short: Indicates whether a transaction is still open or already completed.
transactionStatus.desc: Like package tracking: pending, confirmed, or failed. This allows you to see if everything went smoothly. Sometimes it takes a little time.

gasFee.title: Gas fee
gasFee.short: A fee for computational work in the network.
gasFee.desc: Like a processing fee at the market stall. The busier it is, the more expensive it can become. Not every blockchain calls it gas.

onChain.title: On-Chain
onChain.desc: Like an entry directly into the cash book. Everyone can see it. It's transparent, but often slower or more expensive.

offChain.title: Off-chain
offChain.desc: Like an oral agreement that later gets recorded in the ledger. This can be faster and more cost-effective. Trust plays a bigger role here.

liquidity.title: Liquidity
liquidity.short: Shows how easily something can be handled.
liquidity.desc: The number of buyers and sellers. High liquidity means you can trade quickly without significantly affecting the price. Low liquidity feels sluggish.

volatility.title: Volatility
volatility.desc: Like a market with wild price swings. High volatility means opportunities, but also risk. For beginners, this can be stressful.

marketCap.title: Market capitalization
marketCap.short: The total value of a coin or project.
marketCap.desc: Like the total value of all goods in a market. It is roughly calculated by multiplying price by circulating quantity. Large values may seem more stable, but they are not automatically so.

circulatingSupply.title: Circulation quantity
circulatingSupply.short: The amount of coins that are actually in circulation.
circulatingSupply.desc: Like the number of coins that are actually on the market. Not everything that exists is already in circulation. This influences the price.

priceDiscovery.title: Pricing
priceDiscovery.short: The price is determined by supply and demand.
priceDiscovery.desc: Just like in the market: supply and demand meet. Many small decisions determine the price. There is no fixed switch.

spread.title: Trading range
spread.short: The difference between the purchase price and the selling price.
spread.desc: Like the trading range in a store. The smaller the difference, the fairer it feels. Large spreads make trades more expensive.

phishing.title: Phishing
phishing.short: Fraud through fake news or websites.
phishing.desc: Like a fake bank email that lures you into a trap. The goal is for you to give up your login credentials. Never click on links blindly.

smartContract.title: Smart contract
smartContract.short: A program that automatically executes fixed rules.
smartContract.desc: Like an automaton that reacts according to fixed rules. It executes agreements automatically. This saves trust but requires clear rules.

programmableLogic.title: Automated rules
programmableLogic.short: Rules that automatically execute when something happens.
programmableLogic.desc: Like an if-then rule in an automaton. This allows processes to be controlled without manual intervention each time. This is how simple digital contracts are created.

networkCongestion.title: Network utilization
networkCongestion.short: When a large number of transactions are pending simultaneously.
networkCongestion.desc: Like traffic jams on the highway. Transactions take longer, and fees may increase. With less traffic, it speeds up again.

blockchainTypes.title: Types of Blockchain
blockchainTypes.short: There are different types of blockchains with various objectives.
blockchainTypes.desc: Like different vehicle types for different routes. Some are built for payments, others for programs. It's worth knowing the purpose.

paymentBlockchain.title: Payment blockchain
paymentBlockchain.short: A blockchain designed for fast payments.
paymentBlockchain.desc: Like a quick cash ledger. The focus is on cheap and fast transfers. Features are often intentionally kept simple.

smartContractBlockchain.title: Smart contract blockchain
smartContractBlockchain.short: A blockchain that can run programs and apps.
smartContractBlockchain.desc: Like a market with many machines. In addition to payments, rules and apps can run there. This makes them versatile, but often more complex.

blockchainComparison.title: Blockchain comparison
blockchainComparison.short: A comparison reveals the strengths and weaknesses of different blockchains.
blockchainComparison.desc: Like comparing banks or markets: Each has strengths and weaknesses. Important aspects are cost, speed, and security. There is no perfect system for everything.

stellarVsBitcoinVsEthereum.title: Stellar vs. Bitcoin vs. Ethereum
stellarVsBitcoinVsEthereum.short: Three well-known blockchains with different focuses.
stellarVsBitcoinVsEthereum.desc: Bitcoin is like digital gold and is often viewed as a store of value. Ethereum is like a platform for programs and apps. Stellar is strongly focused on affordable payments.
